column4: I'm neither allowed to logon via root (using GDM), nor alloweded to run anything from System > Administration menu as a normal user. So how should I run System > Administration menu programs?
you should be able to run them using sudo on your original user account
when you start an app from the menu, you should get a window asking for the password
if you don't, run  gksu ls  from a terminal
did you get a window, or an error?
I typed my password to the windows raised, but it gave another error. One sec...
Failed to run ls as user root. The underlying auth mechanism (sudo) does not allow you to run this program.
are you in the admin group?
and is this the original user you created during the install?
In wheel an my own group, not in admin. Must I be?
yes, admin is the group that has sudo privs. And where in the world did you come up with wheel, it's not used in ubuntu
I installed ubuntu-desktop after system installation. Actually, this is a server machine and I never thought to have an X. But I needed to run Windows XP using qemu/kvm.
wheel group is for my su users.
ah. Don't know if the server install does admin group. Worst case, boot into recovery mode and do  adduser <youruser> admin, then type exit. Should be fine then
Heh! I think I can manage to add myself to admin group. ;-)
also,  adm dialout cdrom floppy audio dip video plugdev fuse lpadmin admin are the groups you need to be in for full functionality
I won't need that functionality. I just need a working VNC session to see how Windows XP does.
then you should be fine. At least you know ;)
Thanks so much for your help. I need to get used to that gksu stuff.
personally, I used sudo long before ubuntu, after an encounter with romeo echo in the wrong terminal
I used to use "su -"ed screen session for my administration stuff. I restrict su capability to wheel group, and restrict access of those users via ssh and that's all.
Despite I added vy to admin group, gksu ls still complains.
hm. A silly question: did you log out and back in?
